awd_titl_txt: The evolution of buoyant magnetic structures in the solar interior
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the great challenges in solar physics is to understand how solar magnetic flux floats from the Sun?s deep interior (where it is generated by the solar dynamo) to the surface. Until now, solar physicists have assumed that magnetic flux could be modeled as discrete magnetically buoyant ?flux tubes.? Recent research has suggested that this idealization might be invalid. The work proposed here will expand that work, and rethink current 3D simulations by modeling solar magnetic flux as concentrations of magnetic field embedded in a diffuse background field. If successful, the work will lead to a fundamental shift in our understanding of the evolution and dynamics of the solar magnetic field, and provide insight into the solar dynamo. The results of this work will provide a theoretical basis for DKIST observations of emerging solar magnetic flux, which is one of the principal goals of the new observatory. This work will also form the basis of a PhD thesis.

The proposed work will be to develop a new model for the transport of magnetic flux from deep in the solar interior to the surface through the mechanism of magnetic buoyancy. In particular, the team will replace the idealization of discrete magnetic ?flux tubes? with more physical concentrations of magnetic field set in a diffuse background field. Field lines interweave between the magnetic concentration and the background field, resulting in very different dynamics from what one would expect with discrete flux tubes. This can include mass loss from the rising magnetic concentration, which is prohibited in the flux tube case. They will also increase the fidelity of the simulation by including turbulence in the region through which the magnetic concentration rises. The team will expand prior 2.5D studies into full 3D simulations. This will require the use of supercomputing facilities which were acquired under prior NSF support.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this project are to understand the dynamics of the rise of magnetic structures from the deep solar interior.  Such structures are thought to be the source of the magnetic flux that we observe emerging as active regions and sunspots.   Surprisingly, these observations are remarkably ordered, considering the chaotic environment from which they emerge, and follow distinct rules (e.g. the "butterfly diagram", Hale's Polarity Laws, Joy's Law). 

More recent new observations have focused on the magnetic helicity of these structures.  This quantity is a measure of the twist, writhe and linkage of the magnetic field.  Magnetic helicity is important since it is a strong constraint on dynamo theory (for the origin of the magnetic fields), and since helicity is believed to be a primary trigger for flares and CMEs.  It turns out that this quantity also has a surprisingly ordered behaviour, now known generally as the Solar Hemispheric Helicity Rule (SHHR).  This "rule" states that structures emerge with primarily negative current helicity in the Northern hemisphere and primarily positive current helicity in the Southern hemisphere of the Sun.  The rule is a weak rule, with only 60-70% of active regions obeying it and a significant number of violations.  There is some evidence of temporal changes in the scatter of this rule over the solar cycle. 

The major goals of this project were to understand the origin of the current helicity in rising magnetic structures and therefore the origin of the SHHR.  More particularly, we were working on a theory that the magnetic structures are best characterized as magnetic concentrations embedded in a large-scale field.  To date, most theoretical advances have been based around preconceived idealizations of a magnetic structure that are in general isolated tube-like structures in an otherwise field-free background.  Whilst intuitive, this latter idealization constrains the dynamics quite considerably.  We are working on models that relax these constraints and provide a more realistic model of a magnetic structure as a concentration in a volume-filling magnetic field.  We are finding that indeed the dynamics are substantially different.  These ideas have lead to a new theory for the origin of the SHHR (or, at the very least, a new component that could contribute significantly to this rule that was previously not identified).  It is an understanding of these new dynamics that we were pursuing with this grant.  Ultimately our goal was to compare the contributions to the total current helicity budget of emerging structures from this new mechanism and previously suggested mechanisms, by the use of numerical simulations.

The work in this project revealed the dynamics of the new mechanism.  If magnetic flux concentrations were to be produced (by instabllity) with a random twist, then structures where the twist is aligned with the large scale overlying field at the bottom of the tube gain an extra tension force that makes them more likely to rise than structures with the opposite twist.  This selection mechanism, when placed in the solar context, is commensurate with the SHHR.  Furthermore, this mechanism is very robust, and we have shown that it works when the magnetic structure has to transit a convection zone to emerge at the surface as well as merely a quiescent zone.  The former is substantially more realistic and it is good that the selection mechanism still operates despite the turbulence.   The work under this grant produced both 2.5D and 3D Cartesian numerical simulations which demonstrated the efficacy of this selection mechanism.

This project further investigated the previously leading theory for the origin of the SHHR via numerical simulations.  This theory, known as the Sigma effect, instead derives the origin of the magnetic helicity in the magnetic structures from the writing action of the rotationally-influenced convection through which the structure must transit.  In this scenario, there is a correlation between the rotational influence on the convection (kinetic helicity) and the magnetic helicity.  This effect to date was described by an elegant but highly simplified heuristic model.  Under the auspices of this project, we further conducted 3D numerical simulations to examine this correlation in a situation that incorporated the full dynamics (magnetic structures rising through fully-resolved turbulent rotating convection).  These simulations are very numerically intense.   Although our statistics were crude due to this intensity (i.e. it was expensive to run many Monte Carlo simulations), we found no evidence of the Sigma effect correlation.

The ultimate conclusions of our work are that we have found a new potential source of the SHHR that is distinctly more robust and has distinct advantages over existing theories (such as a simple explanation for violations to the "rule").  We now believe that this is at least a significant component of the origin of the SHHR. 

This grant also substantially contributed to the training of 3 graduate students.
